content.description: Begin on the right trending melted blob seam and make your way up to a jug with a big move.  Traverse right on slopers then move up into more slopers onto a face full of slimpers.  Then pull the roof and mantle to the anchors.
content.location: Begin in the choss beneath the roof.

content.description: After a hold broke, a now ridiculous dyno from micro crimps opens this route and gives it the grade (though the second crux is no slouch).  Moderate face climbing leads to another nails crimp crux out the second roof to a finish with a really wonderful crack feature.
content.location: Middle route on the wall.  Has two bolts coming out the belly.

content.description: A "Trickier-Than-It-Looks" start leads right around the bulge to a good stance before the face.  Decipher the best way to engage the undercling and tech your way up the face beyond it while desperately searching for feet.  Relaxed climbing leads to a harder roof and more quality face climbing up to the chains.
content.location: First route around the corner from the main "Big Shot" zone.   Begins in slopey pods 10ft. left of where the tree touches the cliff up top.

content.description: Furthest left route under the roof.  Climb up a cool flake and then straight into the roof business where you'll find enormous holds and good heal toe cams leading to a feet cutting swing-a-thon at the lip.  Finishes on easier terrain.
content.location: Starts on left leaning flake leading up to the roof.

content.description: In the far back of the large roof look for a hueco resembling ‘8’ then find the smaller but deep and juggy hueco, this is your target.  Start on the face with a good undercling rail and work up to the roof.  Follow the hueco out the roof and pull the face.  Get a chicken wing rest and finish with a fun and techy move to the anchors.
content.location: In the far back of the large roof look for a hueco resembling ‘8’

content.description: Begin on fun face climbing that leads to the crux at the third bolt pulling a small roof.  Continue up interesting movement and holds to a final fun little roof pull. Great and unique for the grade.
content.location: Begins on a left facing slab before the short steep roof that make up Tarzan & Jane

content.description: Climb Summer thunder to the roof.  Extend the last bolt and skip the anchor, clipping the roof bolts instead.  Short and committing roof bouldering on decent holds to a second set of anchors.
content.location: Extension to "summer thunder"

content.description: Start right of first bolt on great layback feature.  Continue to follow the seam/crack up and left for sustained laybacking on smeared feet.  After bolt 5 follow jugs to the right to a rest and more relaxed face.
content.location: Left Around the corner from the big wall and Up the small slippery step.  First route on the right following the left trending layback feature.

content.description: After a fun and engaging initial slab, fall into a world of deep lock-offs, juggs, and huge moves through consistently steep terrain.  Uncomplicated, but rather fatiguing climbing continues until the second-to-last bolt where shit gets real.  A bouldery sequence of crimps and sharp edges ends with a tough move to a slot and a strenuous clip.  Then Launch and hope you have enough to hang on for dear life.
content.location: First route to the left atop the main approach trail.  Begins in a chossy scoop until the first bolt.

content.description: Closed Project, do not climb.
content.location: Starts on blast mound in fist jam crack

climbs.name: Plain Jane
climbs.fa: Equipped: Brad Mathisen FA: Aaron Parlier

content.description: The harder sister of Tarzan. Nothing plain about it! Climb to the roof and make easy moves out to nails hard body tension moves for the better holds near the lip.  Mantle the lip of the roof onto an incredible jug flake system.
content.location: Route to the right of Tarzan

content.description: The route starts on a really beautiful (hard) pinched-off seem.  Make some juggy roof pulls to a stance 3/4 of the way up the wall.
content.location: Just Right of the choss pile, starts on the obvious pinched-off seem.

content.description: This one turned out to be a real gem with a little bit of everything.  Thuggy start, through a roof, then on to a bouldery face crux followed by smearing lay backs.  Very satisfying route for sure.
content.location: Furthest right sport line at Big Shot Wall

content.description: Closed Project
content.location: Route to the right of JourneyMen, Starting about 20 feet right of the wet dihedral under the big roof.

content.description: This is an alternate start to "Too Elite to Excrete".  Begin by coming out the juggy roof exit on the route to the right.  In the middle of the face climb at the 5th bolt traverse left into the face of "TEtE" and finish out the roof and face of that route.  Probably a better and more consistent route if done this way.
content.location: Mash up of "too elite to excrete" and the route to the right.

content.description: Begin by carefully climbing through the first 8 feet of choss that is characteristic of this crag.  Stick Clip the first bolt once on the choss pile as the first few moves are the hardest. Then climb varied features on progressively easing terrain.
content.location: Beneath the choss Pile, under the big roof. Probably stays dry in rain.

content.description: Probably the best route here so far.  Until Kyle sends the one next to it, then it will be a tie.
content.location: Route beginning on dark red rock before the wet dihedral under the big roof near the top of the approach trail for Big Shot Crag.

content.description: Great Climbing with a challenging roof traverse section up high.  I'd recommend climbing the initial 8' of choss then stick clipping.
content.location: Route Just Right of the big roof where "Just Your Opinion" is.

content.description: Moderate start leads to hard moves through the ruffles and up to some tricky bulges.  Stick clip after summiting the initial choss pile
content.location: Middle of the three routes that begin on the choss and then go through the beautiful butter ruffle panel.

content.description: Really Fun jug moves out an initial roof open into moderate face climbing on good rock.  A no hands shake sets you up nicely before the second crux pull and mantle (?) out the second roof.  Keep your wits about you as the final face is no gimme.
content.location: Middle Route on the Wall, starts out jug rails, plates, and pockets.

content.description: Like two great routes stacked on top of one another.  The first half starts way out left with the same intro as Big Shot.  After climbing to the roof, clip the bolt around the corner to the right (first bolt of Black Lung) and back clean the other bolt.  Climb an excellent and extremely burly boulder problem out the roof through big hidden pockets with some serious throws and campus moves to get to the face.  From here the route goes soft for a bit with a no hands rest.  The upper headwall starts the business back with sustained pumpy climbing on good holds to a heartbreaker red point crux to the chains.  (it is possible to hang an extended draw from the anchor and skip this move,  that does not count as a send.  Don't cheat yourself from a superb finish).
content.location: Right most route next to trail just past two mile marker.

content.description: Big Intimidating looking Line On the main prow right off the trail at Mile 2.  Start down and left of bolt line and climb easy moves into the diving board roof flake.  (Climb at Your Own Risk, I never felt scare while climbing it, but it's obviously an enormous block that has a crack on it).  Pull onto the immaculate face for big holds until the crack.  Beautiful sequential climbing leads through the seam and into a sitdown rest.  Pull out of the rest into a power endurance sequence ending in one of the stranger redpoint crux moves I've done to gain the feet cutting jug on the arete before the chains.  excellent and unique climbing.
content.location: Left Route directly next to the trail at 2 mile marker.  Climbs out the roof on a big diving board

content.description: Just before the big cap roof with ‘Tarzan’ and to the left of the slab start to ‘Sweatpants’.  Start on some fun face climbing and pull the roof with some good jugs and a tricky mantle.    FA:  Marshall Gilbert, Developed 7/10/2019     *May be extended 20-30 ft. in the distant future*
content.location: left of the slab start to ‘Sweatpants’

content.description: This is crag is the proudest looking crag in the entire gorge.  80-90 ft. walls of perfect rock with morning shade and afternoon sun.  The routes here tend to be a bit harder, but probably more awesome.  One  thing to note is that the NFS does not want development on routes that overhang the trail.  Sorry, they look incredible.
